Fields.DialogueText: Nenohi! Good to see you. Are you enjoying being the hub of our little fleet as much as you thought you would?
Oh, it is so much fun, Kanchou. I speak to everyone and everyone speaks to me. I am learning so many things about the others.
Did you know that the Russians make a drink of potatoes? A drink of roots. So silly.
And the English have tea that is much like Chinese tea. They say that they make it better, but I cannot tell.
I'm glad to hear you're enjoying the experience. I know you wanted to be able to relate better to your fleet mates.
It is so nice to learn about other nationalities - and about my fellow ships as well. We have so much in common, and such interesting differences.

Fields.MenuText: As long as your chats aren't getting in the way of your work, I'm happy you're having a nice time.
It's good to hear you're having such a nice time talking to the others. I bet the rest of the fleet appreciates your interest.
Keep your eyes on the prize, Nenohi. We're still fighting a war here, after all.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course not, Kanchou. While at work, I am the epitome of professionalism.
Karera wa sore ga sukida to omou. I'm glad to put a smile on their faces.
Yes, Kanchou. Still, I won't stop talking to my friends among the fleet.
*ALARM*
It's time to put your war hat on, Nenohi. Gossip will have to wait.
@BATTLE
What's wrong, Nenohi? You look more downtrodden than I'm used to seeing you.
Oh, Kanchou, it's nothing. Daijōbudesu.
Please. I can tell that something is bothering you, even if you try to hide it.
...Fine, Kanchou, if you insist on knowing. I am simply saddened that my stamp collection is not growing.
That's a problem that should be easily remedied. Is there something I can do to help?
I do not believe so, Kanchou. With the war on, fewer new stamps are being created, and there is little time to look for them.
My collection is one of the many reasons I hope for a speedy end to this war. Then, I'll be able to visit new lands and learn more of their histories through tiny pictures.

Fields.MenuText: I can't say that I've heard stamps described as a window into history before.
Who knows, though? In two weeks' time we might dock somewhere you've never been, and the stamp hunt can resume.
I suppose that's something to worry about when the war ends, isn't it? Until then, we have monsters to fight.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, but they are. Immortalizing the moments that mean the most to the country that issues them.
I do hope so, Kanchou - that would make me very happy. I will fight harder with this as my goal.
Of course, Kanchou. It was just a moment of reflection. It will not affect my duties.
The Morganas are up ahead, by the way. I came to tell you to make ready for battle.
@BATTLE
And can you believe what Augusta said about Argonaut? I had no idea the ships of one nation could have such strong opinions about one another.
Okay, hold on. I doubt that Augusta would like you spreading this stuff around.
Oh, I am sure it is fine, Kanchou. They are friends, are they not? And sisters in arms.
And if I told your sisters about your "capsizing problem", would you be upset?
Of course, Kanchou! I told you that in confidence.
So...
Ah. I see what you mean, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: If people are talking to you, they are doing it because they want you to know something. Not because they want to spread it around.
Now would you do me a favor and cut out the gossip? I don't want a feud on my hands.
Loose lips sink ships, Nenohi.

Fields.DialogueText: You're correct about that, of course. Gomen'nasai. It will not happen again.
Oh, of course, Kanchou. I do not wish any Belles to be upset with me, nor their crews.
Oh, that is very chilling. Did you come up with that on your own?
Oh, Kanchou, we have reports of the enemy to the north. We'd best be on our way.
@BATTLE
Kanchou! Kanchou, I would like you to come look at my decorations. If you have the time?
I think I can spare a minute. You seem very proud of yourself.
Wow. That's a lot of red and blue streamers.
It took a while, I'll admit.
You have quite the sense of decoration, don't you?
Aw, thanks, Kanchou.
What's the occasion, anyhow? Is it someone's birthday today? I see you've made a cake.
I did and it is. It's the birthday of an American friend of mine, and I tried to make her an appropriate display. I even have coffee.
I'm sure she'll appreciate it, Nenohi. How do you plan on fitting an entire party of people in here, though? Space is a bit scarce.

Fields.MenuText: ... Is it time for an emergency brainstorming session?
It seems you may have overlooked a crucial point in your haste to prepare a suitable party.
It looks like you've wasted a fair amount of time, haven't you?

Fields.DialogueText: I... may not have planned for all of the necessary aspects of this party.
I did not, I just need to find a solution to this problem. Maybe I could move these decorations to the mess hall?
Nothing is a waste of time if you learn something. And I have certainly learned something.
*ALARM*
There's the alarm, let's put a pin in this party. That will give you time to come up with a plan.
How considerate of our enemies.
@BATTLE
Over four hundred!
I believe it. Oh, and those stars hanging from ceiling are very nice.
Go shinsetsu ni dōmo! Thank you!
This must have taken you some time.
Nenohi, has anything odd been happening with your radio recently? I've been getting some strange reports.
Nothing too odd, Kanchou. There has been more interference lately, but that is all.
And there's nothing that bothers you about the interference? Has the radio been this bad before?
There could be some other Protection Fleet ships in the area, Kanchou. Competing signals tend to get garbled, you know.
Strange. Several people have complained about it. But I guess we'll see if it stops when we move on.
Sōnaruto īdesu ne. I'll keep my eyes peeled in case some other explanation presents itself.

Fields.MenuText: I appreciate that, Nenohi. It's important for us to be cautious, just in case.
Thank you, Nenohi. I'd rather not have our communications curtailed at a crucial moment.
Good. I'm sure your assistance is not at all motivated by the threat of being unable to speak to your friends.

Fields.DialogueText: I understand, Kanchou. We are at war after all. The careless fish is the first caught, after all.
I understand, Kanchou. Believe me when I say that I understand the importance of solid communications.
Oh, it most certainly is, Kanchou. I do not wish to find myself in that position.
All right, I'm glad that's settled. Now, we have an engagement soon, so be prepared.
I will see to myself and the rest of the ship.
@BATTLE
Nenohi, you seem to be enjoying yourself.
Hai! Very much so, Kanchou. Even with the radios being so scratchy, I am very much loving the time I spend with my sisters in arms.
I'm even getting to know many of their crew members. They've promised to write me when we part ways.
I'm sure this desire for pen pals has nothing to do with your quest for more stamps.
Do not taint the purity of my interactions, Kanchou. I am very interested in learning more about the world.
...And I'm going to get so many stamps from so many places. I am so excited about it!

Fields.MenuText: Do your erstwhile penpals know they are being used for their stamp acquisition potential?
It is good to see you taking an interest in our crew members, and not just the other Belles.
Either way, don't let your stamp hunting get in the way of your duties. We have to keep this fleet together.

Fields.DialogueText: They know enough. I have strongly hinted that they should correspond with their best stamps.
Everyone has interesting stories, Kanchou. They are from all over, and they have seen so many things.
Of course, Kanchou. I will not let my fraternizing become a liability.
Well, do me a favor and let all of your friends know that we'll have a fight on our hands sooner rather than later.
Touzen. No one will lose sight of that, Kanchou - we do love a good fight.
@BATTLE
Nenohi, I need to ask you something. Have you picked up on some strange signals from the crew?
Do you mean strange radio signals, Kanchou? Not particularly.
Sorry. I phrased that badly - I meant strange or troubling sentiments.
I can't say that I have. Although, now that you mention it, some of my regular offboard conversationalists have made themselves scarce.
How odd. From what I'm hearing, other ships are dealing with mounting frustrations.
You haven't noticed any troubles with our crew here, though?
Not particularly. They all seem as happy and absorbed in their duties as ever.

Fields.MenuText: Would you mind asking around to see if there's anyone who will talk to you about what's happening?
I'm sure it's nothing, but do me a favor and keep an eye out for me. You seem to have a lot of confidants these days.
Look into it, and keep an eye on your crew. Cohesion is what keeps the fleet together.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, Kanchou, although I can't imagine what could be driving people apart in the fleet.
I will. You did tell me not to go spreading rumors around, but I'm sure I can find a happy medium.
Hai. I understand, Kanchou, and I will do my duty.
In the meantime, I think we can keep the fleet working together through the next engagement.
I'm sure we can, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, I have a request for you, if it's not too great a burden.
Oh, believe me, I'll let you know if it is. But what do you need?
I was looking at our forecast, and we will need to make a refueling stop soon. I was hoping to suggest the port we could stop at.
If it's not too far out of our way, I don't suppose it'll be a problem. Why is it important to you for us to stop there?
Well... I may have heard something about there being a few rather rare stamps there, among the shops in the port.
You want me to turn the fleet just on the off chance you can perhaps locate a stamp you would otherwise miss?
...Yes.

Fields.MenuText: You have got to be out of your mind. There is no way stamps are influencing our plans.
Well, it's not particularly out of our way, and Morgana activity has been minimal lately. I'll look into it.
How about we wait for the war to end before we go back to stamp collecting, all right? There are a few other considerations.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, but Kanchou, I'll never ask you for anything again. Please, Kanchou.
Arigatōgozaimasu! I promise, you will not regret it if you decide to honor my request.
Of course, Kanchou. Gomen'nasai! I never meant to put my desires ahead of the safety of the fleet.
*ALARM*
Let's table this - we have work to do.
@BATTLE
Nenohi, why do your sailors appear to be going for a swim? With tow cables, no less?
Ha, well... I may have overdone it on my maneuvers earlier, and it is possible that I did so while there was unsecured gear on the deck.
So now, there is the possibility that my brave sailors are attempting to reel in several slowly sinking freight crates.
Didn't we have a talk about not overstressing your superstructure or attempting tight turns?
That was about maneuvers during combat, Kanchou. This was a non-combat scenario. Completely different.
So you didn't overbalance and lose several valuable crates of supplies?
I certainly haven't lost them yet, Kanchou. I know exactly where they are.

Fields.MenuText: You need to be more careful, Nenohi. We can't afford to lose anything out here. We have a war to fight.
Try not to tip so far next time. I don't want to see any of our people dropping into the drink unexpectedly.
Well. I suppose those sailors are getting some good exercise, at least.

Fields.DialogueText: I understand, Kanchou. Of course.
Me neither, Kanchou! I think I have learned from this mistake.
Have I mentioned how much I appreciate your ability to look on the bright side, Kanchou? Because I appreciate it very much.
*ALARM*
Get those men reeled in, cargo or no cargo. We need them at their posts.
Yabai. I'm sorry, Kanchou, I think we lost those crates.
@BATTLE
What's wrong, Nenohi? It's always strange to see you in a sour mood.
Gomen'nasai. I am finally receiving radio broadcasts from the homeland. They are... not my favorite.
I would've assumed word from home would be a comfort in times like these.
Not for me. The Japanese government is full of old men who have never seen a day of hard work in their lives, sending young men to go out and die.
They do it on the premise that the Japanese are better than all others. I have seen others. I have made friends among many people.
I knew Japanese government officials were fools before, but now? Now I think they will lead us to ruin.
I'm sorry, Nenohi. If it makes you feel better, you will always have a family with the fleet, no matter what happens.

Fields.MenuText: You've made so many friends here. You don't need to be beholden to the wishes of your government.
You are strong and independent, and you make your own choices in life. Don't let them force you to do anything that would conflict with your own moral code.
If nothing else, they agreed to the truce that made the fleet. They can't be all bad.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, Kanchou, and I am reminded of that every day. Thank you, I feel at home here.
I will not, Kanchou. I know better than that.
Self interest does not a good man make, Kanchou. I think we both know that.
*ALARM*
Time to protect my true family once again.
@BATTLE
Nenohi, I've had a few more reports about unrest around the fleet. Are you getting the same impression?
Hai. I'm hearing stories too - but it makes no sense. Tensions are rising up for no reason.
It's can't be for no reason. There must be some root. But I'm having difficulty investigating the issue.
Crews are being split along national lines, but I do not see a cause. Why are these frustrations coming to a head now?
And why is this happening all over the fleet? I want to know how many ships have been affected by this.
Too many, I fear. Japanese, Soviets, Europeans, Americans... all nations have been accounted for, unfortunately. Kiken ni naritsutsu arimasu.

Fields.MenuText: I need to know what's causing this. The greatest threat to the fleet is internal division.
But everything's okay here.  It wouldn't be fair to say I wish every Belle could be like you, but...
I need these people to get their minds back in their work, Nenohi. Can I count on you to help me?

Fields.DialogueText: I will do my best to hunt down the responsible party, but it feels as if we're only finding dead ends right now, Kanchou.
This isn't the fault of my sisters-in-arms, Kanchou. Don't let yourself be distracted from finding the real threat.
You can, and the Belles are determined to get to the bottom of the issue as well. We'll figure it out, one way or another.
*ALARM*
Damn. Thank you, Nenohi. Now, let's teach this Morgana a lesson.
@BATTLE
I don't think I'm insulting anyone else when I say what you're doing deserves to be emulated. It...
Things are starting to get out of hand, Nenohi. Whoever is spreading this dissent is causing a real problem.
Watashi mo onaji kangae desu. But why now? The fleet has only become more diverse and understanding over time. Surely this should have been a bigger problem in the first days of the war.
I'm not sure, Nenohi, but we'll get to the bottom of this. In the meantime, I need to ask a favor of you.
What is it, Kanchou? I am at your disposal.
I need you to be an ambassador on behalf of the crews of other ships. Can you help them bridge the gaps being torn?
M-me, Kanchou? There are so many Belles with more experience as diplomats.

Fields.MenuText: Because the crews of the fleet like you. You take an interest in people, and that matters to them more than rhetoric.
Because I asked you to. Trust me, you are a good fit for the role.
If you don't want it, I'll give the job to someone else.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose that's true, Kanchou. Very well, I shall try to help my fellows get along.
...I will trust you, Kanchou. It's a lot of pressure, but for the fleet, I'm willing to bear it.
No, no, I can do this for you Kanchou. I am not sure how, but I will do my best.
*ALARM*
Good, now look alive. We have enemies headed this way, and I want us working like a well-oiled machine.
Such a rush. I will do my very best.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, it is far worse than either of us believed. The tensions are growing greatly, and I worry they will soon boil over.
What do you mean? I thought you were in the process of talking everyone around.
I was, but the crews are so very angry. Even some of the Belles are becoming short with each other.
The worst of it is, the things everyone says have the bitter sting of truth. People speak of invasions and wars gone by.
There are few countries in the fleet that have not come to blows in the past, and each and every person feels them.
That's bizarre. I heard an American crewman earlier taunting the British for the battle of Yorktown. I thought it was just a joke.
Gomen'nasai. It is very real, and I don't know how to address it. I am worried that soon they will come to blows.

Fields.MenuText: Do what you can, Nenohi. We'll find the root cause of this sooner or later, and then we'll burn it out.
Well, I appreciate your help. I'll start asking around to see if any of the senior officers have any idea why this is happening.
If they do, I'm going to think hard about bringing back flogging. This is not the place for petty squabbles.

Fields.DialogueText: Hai. I will help all of the fleet see we must come together against these monsters.
I will ask among the crews. Someone must know who is to blame.
I hope it does not come to that, Kanchou - but I will let the fleet know you are very serious about this matter.
*ALARM*
Ah. We must be on our way.
@BATTLE
It's got to be good for crew solidarity, anyway.
Kanchou! Kite kudasatte, arigatōgozaimasu. I wanted you to hear this for yourself.
I assume it's important. You sounded almost flustered when you asked for me.
Lean down by this radio and listen to this.
...In the Hundred Years War, the French and English fought each other with merciless and treacherous tactics...
What is this? Who is saying this? Is it just a history lesson? I mean, an extremely loaded history lesson?
More or less, Kanchou. I have listened to it for a few minutes, and it seems to simply tell stories.
There are several other frequencies, each in a different language. All tell of various wars, massacres and atrocities committed against the speakers of that language.

Fields.MenuText: How did you find out about these broadcasts?
Do you have any idea where this is coming from?
How many different languages have you found?

Fields.DialogueText: I was trying to find a frequency to use. I simply stumbled upon it.
I do not. It must be close by, though.
A dozen or so, all of them spoken in the fleet. It's fortunate I've taken the time to practice so many—I'm not sure I would have recognized them otherwise.
*ALARM*
We have a fight on our hands, but once we're done, this is our number one priority.
@BATTLE
Have you made any progress finding the source of those broadcasts, Nenohi?
Gomen'nasai! Progress has been slow - the signal is too faint to track. Still, I've made a few discoveries on the subject.
First, it appears that most of the affected crews have some experience with the broadcasts. They were reluctant to talk about them, but most knew of their existence.
Second, they appreciate them. They enjoy listening and did not like the idea of me stopping the broadcasts.
They like them? Why? It's making everyone so angry.
They are entertaining, Kanchou. Each one paints its listeners as the heroes, and it's history, so they feel as if they've learned something.

Fields.MenuText: The present is more important than the past. We need to put a stop to this.
Maybe I should listen to a broadcast. It might contain some clue as to its source.
Well, damn - it's hard to take away a sailor's favorite toy.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, Kanchou, but this may be harder than we thought.
If you believe you can do so without becoming indoctrinated by hatred, Kanchou, by all means.
Hah, they are like cats, then? Should we take the radios when they are finished being silly?
*ALARM*
Okay. A fight should give our minds a break from the matter.
It is worrying to look forward to being refreshed by battle, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
There were three more fights around the fleet today. One man is in the infirmary because another took a chair to him.
Oh, no, Kanchou - is he going to be okay?
I think so. I'm tempted to confiscate and lock down every radio I can reach, but that might make things worse.
Right now I can turn a blind eye to crew members letting off steam against each other, but someone is going to cross a line I can't ignore if this keeps up.
Oh, goodness, Kanchou. You are serious about this. But I suppose it is a serious matter.
Ships are powder kegs, Nenohi. You know this. All this energy and no outlet. If we don't stop it soon, I fear where it will lead.
If we make it to that point, the Morganas will no longer be our greatest adversaries.

Fields.MenuText: Let's make sure we don't get to that point, then. Tell me some good news.
If I have to keep this war going by myself, I will. But to win, we'll need everyone's help.
I know. And if we fall apart, it will doom everyone.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm afraid I do not have much. The officers are largely unaffected, but the crews are just getting worse.
I will always be here with you, Kanchou. We can fight to the last together.
I will do my best to make sure that does not happen, Kanchou.
*ALARM*
We know what we have to do, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
Here we go again.
Kanchou! I have news. I do not know if it is good, but it is a development, for certain.
All right, slow down. What do you have for me?
Our nemesis has a name. One of the sailors told me that the speaker signs off occasionally, and does so with her name.
I was able to listen long enough to hear it, although she does not say it often.
Well, don't keep me in suspense.
It's Fushin - Mistrust, Kanchou. The Funayūrei.

Fields.MenuText: Well, it does seem as if she should have been one of the obvious culprits.
You're sure it's the Morgana? Not a human masquerading as one?
What good does this information do us, Nenohi?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure what would give you that idea.
I don't think a human would be capable of an operation of this magnitude.
It lets us know who to look for. No matter how many Morganas throw themselves at us, we're only interested in one.
*ALARM*
Sounds as if the Morganas want to keep us busy.
I can't imagine why.
@BATTLE
Very funny.
Nenohi, I wanted to let you know that we were able to make that course correction you asked for.
You mean I will have the chance to go stamp hunting after all? Dōmo arigatōgozaimasu!
Well, it made a certain amount of strategic sense. The Morganas won't expect this sort of course deviation.
Kanchou, I am elated to hear this. My poor book of stamps has been so bereft.
And with this breakdown of community in the fleet, I have even been receiving fewer letters.
Well, I'm glad I could make your day. We should make port fairly soon.
Ha! I know, I was marking it on my map out of hope. I am so ecstatic for this, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: I had no idea anyone could be this excited over stamps, but it is good to see you so happy.
This is a military operation, not a shopping trip. Don't get too excited.
Just don't let your desire for stamps get in the way of resupplying, okay?

Fields.DialogueText: I will spread my happiness throughout the ship. Throughout the fleet, if I'm able.
I promise to only be a moderate amount of excited, Kanchou. I will be a model of poise.
I wouldn't dream of it, Kanchou, I am a warship, after all. I will see that my hold is full of munitions! ...As well as stamps.
*ALARM*
There's the alarm. It looks like we'll have to push through Morganas to get to the port.
@BATTLE
Where is everyone? The piers should be swarming with people and boats. It's not every day a Belle comes to visit.
I'm not sure, but our officers should be reporting back soon.
Hai. I'm receiving their reports over the radio right now. ...It sounds like the town was recently hit.
By Morganas? Did they know we were coming?
I think it's something else, Kanchou. They found bodies, bullet casings, and tracks. It looks like an army came through the town.
Do we know which one? They probably took the civilians for labor. The ones who survived, at least.
No, and it likely wouldn't do the civilians much good even if we did. Ships aren't cut out for land rescue missions.
...True enough.
We'd best find what we came for and go on our way.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not comfortable robbing the town, Nenohi.
Is there anything left for us to take? Any army that took the townspeople would surely have stripped the town of materiel.
Get the officers back here. We have enough fuel to make it to another stop.

Fields.DialogueText: We can leave money behind for the goods we purchase. Even if no one ever returns to this town...
The officers reported some remaining, but not much. We'll have to make do with what we can find until we make our next stop.
I have already begun, Kanchou. They should be back aboard soon.
*ALARM*
There's the alarm. It looks like we'll be fighting our way out.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, it's getting worse. That ruined town is fueling all manner of resentment amongst the fleet.
We need to stop this now. If we don't calm these tensions, the Morganas will succeed in using this chaos to their advantage. And with what's happening on land...
What is happening on land, Kanchou? I receive news from Japan occasionally, but I trust it little.
It's just getting worse every day. At the rate we're going, Europe will soon be filled with ruined towns like the one we saw.
We need to focus the fleet on the Funayūrei threat. Mistrust is trying to distract us from the fact that they're our biggest enemy.
Until we stop her broadcasts, we need to work even harder to keep the fleet afloat.

Fields.MenuText: Nenohi, I need you to talk to them, all of them. Maybe we can get the crews to see reason.
Have you thought of any way we might halt Mistrust's broadcasts?
We might need to start confiscating radios.

Fields.DialogueText: I can do that, Kanchou. I think. I may have an idea on what could bring them together, as well.
Perhaps, if I were to put out my own broadcasts on the same frequencies...?
That won't be necessary, Kanchou. I think we ought to give them something else to listen to.
Bring me a plan, Nenohi. I'll make sure you receive whatever help you need.
@BATTLE
Now, look alive - there are Morganas headed this direction.
Morganas incoming!  Battlestations, everyone!
@BATTLE
Are you ready, Nenohi? I'm hoping you can make a big splash with this one.
Hai. Kanchou, I was born ready.
I asked everyone to tune their radios to your frequency, so there shouldn't be anything standing in your way.

Fields.MenuText: Knock `em dead.
I hope you know what you're doing. Otherwise, we're going to have a lot of angry sailors and annoyed officers.
Hurry up, then - we know the Morganas will be on us soon.

Fields.DialogueText: We need to find you less violent metaphors, Kanchou.
I always know what I'm doing, Kanchou. Now hush and let me get to work.
I will not stop this broadcast, even for them.
Kon'nichiwa. Ladies and gentlemen of the fleet, this is Nenohi speaking. I have something to say to you all.
You are all such brave, strong people, and you have come together for a truly excellent purpose.
So today, in your honor, and to your credit, I will tell you the story of how the fleet came to be.
Before I do, though, you must all know that the fleet is in jeopardy. Not just from the monsters of the sea, but from ourselves.
We are the only ones who can stop the Funayūrei - the Morganas. If we fail today due to infighting, there will be no one else to stand between the enemy and our loved ones at home.
You must choose today to stand with your brothers and sisters of the fleet, so that the fleet can save the world.
Write a new chapter with me, my friends. The fleet is my country. And now, our story begins.
We have Morganas incoming!  Looks like Nenohi's broadcast is getting on their nerves.
@BATTLE
You're getting rave reviews, did you know that? Your message is being played throughout the fleet.
Sōdesu ka? Did Command order them to do so, I wonder?
I'm sure they encouraged listening - but no, I think the crews do so of their own volition.
You think any Japanese listeners might view your allegiance to the fleet as somewhat... subversive?
If they do, I do not care. The fleet is my first responsibility.
Fair enough. The fleet is my first responsibility as well.
By the way, you'll never guess who else was listening.
Who's that?
Mistrust. Once she discovered her broadcasts were being ignored, she pumped up the power of her broadcasts. We're headed her direction now.
Oh, I would very much like to show her what I think of her, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: Of course. No one messes with the fleet and gets away with it..
Revenge can't be our primary motivation. Protecting the fleet, however, can.
This could turn into quite the show. Perhaps I should sell tickets.

Fields.DialogueText: I am looking forwards to this, Kanchou. Dōmo arigatōgozaimasu.
You are such a stickler, Kanchou. I will remember these phrasings for later.
Kanchou!
All right, Nenohi, that's Mistrust. If you have any choice words for her, you should have them at the ready.
Oh, I have a speech prepared for this monster. The things she tried to do to the fleet cannot be forgiven.
It isn't just that she tried to break us. The fleet is my home. It is a home to many crews and Belles. And she wanted to destroy that home.
I want her to know exactly what I think of her.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure we have time for a speech, but a few choice radio taunts will probably do the trick.
Just remember that our primary goal is to stop her broadcast, not to tell her what we think of her.
This ought to be good.

Fields.DialogueText: Do not worry, Kanchou. My words will only take a moment, and I'm sure she'll feel their effect.
Of course, Kanchou. I have not forgotten what is most important.
Well, there's no reason to look quite that entertained.
What's with that look you have on your face? What do you have planned?
I wrote everything I have to say to her on my torpedos. Now, are we going to wait around all day? There's a monster to slay.
Full speed ahead it is.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, it is working. Mistrust is fleeing and her broadcast has stopped. I think we might be in the clear.
Defeating a monster like her was no easy task. Thank you for your dedication to seeing this through, Nenohi. The INPF owes you a debt of gratitude.
It was my responsibility. I hope now that the affected crews will be able to put their differences aside.
Without Mistrust's voice in their ears, I'm confident they will.
I am so pleased right now, Kanchou. I honestly don't know that I could be any happier.
Revel in it while you can - we have another mission awaiting us. How is your armament loadout?
I may have fired on Mistrust more than was strictly necessary, but I am by no means defenseless.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad to hear it.
We ought to make a stop soon for supplies, then.
I imagine you'll have quite the stack of letters waiting for you in the coming weeks.

Fields.DialogueText: You know how protective I am of the fleet.
I'll make sure we do.
I hadn't thought of that! What a thrill that will be.
*ALARM*
Sounds as if we have company.
So it does. Shigoto ni torikakarou.
@BATTLE
At this point, I would say so.
Are you in here, Nenohi? It looks like a blizzard hit your quarters.
Letters, Kanchou! Letters from crewmen and women and officers and the Belles...so many letters!
There are so many stamps, and they are from all over the world! I‘m in heaven.
I suppose someone must have told the crew how much you appreciate receiving letters.
Someone, indeed. Thank you, Kanchou. I am so looking forward to seeing what everyone has sent. Some have even included pictures!
I'm glad. I'm glad the crew recognizes how much you've done for all of us. We would not have made it this far without you.
Kanchou, you're getting sentimental now. If you go on like this, I might need to use a handkerchief.

Fields.MenuText: Well, we can't have that, can we?
Let's test this theory. You're a good friend and an excellent confidante who has really found her place in the fleet.
Just don't let these letter distract you from your duties, all right? We still have a lot of work to do.

Fields.DialogueText: Kanchou, is this letter from you? It has your name on it–
Kanchou, is this letter from you? It has your name on it–
Kanchou, is this letter from you? It has your name on it–
Oh, look at the time! I left a strategy meeting in the oven, I must be going.
Silly Kanchou.
